oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Hume High School, circa 1859
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A page from a mounted and bound volume of twenty-five pen-and-ink wash drawings, and two pen-and-ink maps of Nashville created by William A. Eichbaum during the 1850s. Eichbaum was a Nashville bookseller and resident for fifty years. This drawing is of the Hume School, erected in 1853 on the corner of Broad and Spruce streets. After Alfred Hume returned from a six-week study of the public school systems in the Northeast, the architect chosen for Nashville's first public school was Maj. Adolphus Heiman. The school's architectural style was that of Gothic Revival, a style that had become most popular in Nashville just before the Civil War. As Nashville's first successful public school building, Hume School was named for Alfred Hume, "the father of the public school system of Nashville." The Hume School eventually merged with Fogg High School in 1912 to form present day Hume-Fogg High School. A new school building was constructed on the site where the previous two schools had been razed. Forms part of the William A. Eichbaum Sketchbook. 1 drawing : col. ; 5.75 x 9 in.
